--- Kenneth Owen Stanley <kstanley@...>
wrote:
> Tyler,
> 
> So what are you trying next with your project?  I
> think the natural motion
> thing shows this can be done, but what's interesting
> is the simplicity of
> their neural representation.  It suggests that you
> could get much more sophisticated
> behaviors if you did the same thing with NEAT and
> let it run a long time.

So far this semester I've been trying to develop a
solid, expandable framework that I can use to study
the more important stuff (neural net inputs, evolution
parameters, fitness functions).  Now I'm putting the
finishing touches on the joint proportional derivative
controllers.  Here's my to-do list:

* data visualization (networks, speciation)
* XML data storage
* better human model using actual data for joint
limits, body part location/size/center of mass, etc.
* more fitness functions
* better neural net inputs

> One thing I thought of was eventually coevolving
> them to try to knock each other over,
> like a fighting simulation.  Then you could even
> play against one the evolved 
> fighters and it might make an interesting game,
> where punches and kicks are
> real and the bodies actually have to try to keep
> balance.

That would be awesome.  I daydream about cool fitness
functions like this... once the basics have been
accomplished.  Here's my wist list of possible fitness
functions to try:

* standing, jumping, walking
* breaking through walls
* stacking boxes to build towers
* throwing things at an object to knock it down
* pushing others off of a platform (�king of the
mountain�)
* recognizing shapes (present human with a shape, take
it away, then place several shapes around and have
them walk toward the correct shape)
* swimming
* staying balanced amidst an earthquake
* staying balanced with unpredictable ground friction
* staying balanced with unpredictable wind direction
and magnitude

Tyler
